docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans in the Senate argued that private insurers were already negotiating large discounts for Medicare beneficiaries.

headline.main: Senate Bars Medicare Talks for Lower Drug Prices
headline.print_headline: Senate Bars Medicare Talks For Lower Prices on Drugs

docs.snippet: Republicans in the Senate argued that private insurers were already negotiating large discounts for Medicare beneficiaries.

docs.lead_paragraph: A pillar of the Democrats' program tumbled on Wednesday when the Senate blocked a proposal to let Medicare negotiate lower drug prices for millions of older Americans, a practice now forbidden by law. Democrats could not muster the 60 votes needed to take up the measure in the face of staunch opposition from Republicans. The opponents said private insurers and their agents, known as pharmacy benefit managers, were already negotiating large discounts for Medicare beneficiaries.

headline.main: Senate Bars Medicare Talks For Lower Prices on Drugs

docs.abstract: Senate blocks proposal by Democrats to let Medicare negotiate lower drug prices for millions of older Americans, practice now forbidden by law; opposition says private insurers and their agents, known as pharmacy benefit managers, are already negotiating large discounts for Medicare benificiaries; Republicans frame issue as choice between government-run health care and benefit managed by private sector (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The early economic advisers to presidential candidates can leave a big imprint if their candidate prevails.

headline.main: The Advisers Are Writing Our Future
headline.print_headline: Assessing The Advisers In the ’08 Race

docs.snippet: The early economic advisers to presidential candidates can leave a big imprint if their candidate prevails.

keywords.value: White House Council of Economic Advisers
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: In the late 1990s, a small team of economists began traveling down to Austin, Tex., for occasional visits with Gov. George W. Bush, then an unannounced candidate for president. The economists were mostly old Republican policy hands. The youngest member of the group -- the only one who hadn't worked for Ronald Reagan or Gerald Ford -- was Glenn Hubbard, a Columbia professor in his early 40s. After Mr. Bush won, Mr. Hubbard went on to become the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and an architect of the tax cuts that -- love them or hate them -- have undeniably been the centerpiece of Mr. Bush's domestic policy. Mr. Hubbard was later responsible for bringing Ben Bernanke, then a professor at Princeton, into the Bush orbit.

headline.main: Assessing The Advisers In the '08 Race

docs.abstract: David Leonhardt column on economic policy advisers to some presidential candidates; says Douglas Holtz-Eakin is John McCain's director of economic policy; holds Barack Obama's lead economist is Austan Goolsbee; says Hillary Clinton's team is dominated by Roger Altman, Gene Sperling and Dick Gehphardt; holds John Edwards is relying on network of former aides from Capitol Hill; says Mitt Romney's advisers are Glenn Hubbard, Gregory Mankiw and John F Cogan (M)
